executive_summary.top_exposures_note: US geographic dependence with declining market share (38% U.S. EV share in August 2025), lithium supply risk, policy shift ending EV tax credits.

exposure_items.description: CATL lithium mine restart indicating ongoing supply constraints for battery input materials
Tesla robotaxi rollout (early-stage), potentially diversifying demand beyond vehicle sales
US EV market share slipped to 38%, reflecting competitive demand pressure in Tesla's key domestic market

policy_hooks.description: US federal EV tax credits program ending per new legislation, reducing price incentives affecting demand for Tesla EVs
Tesla's ~3% weight in Nasdaq-100 ETF (QQQ) implies index fund trading flows influence stock price dynamics

risk_paths: Lithium supply constraints → potential battery input cost inflation → upward pressure on TSLA production costs
US EV credit expiry → reduced buyer incentives → potential demand contraction in domestic market
High beta (3.11) → amplified stock price moves relative to market swings → increased volatility exposure
QQQ ETF rebalancing or large inflows/outflows → magnified impact on TSLA stock price due to index inclusion & weighting
monitoring_triggers: Announcement or adjustments in US EV incentive programs/policies
CATL and lithium supply chain updates affecting battery raw material availability/pricing
Tesla's U.S. EV sales share updates in September 2025
Nasdaq-100 ETF rebalance schedule or quarterly holdings update (~mid-September)
Tesla quarterly earnings or key product announcements impacting investor sentiment
Broader market volatility shifts impacting high-beta stocks like TSLA

market_volatility_impact.headline: High Volatility Analysis
paragraphs: TSLA's unusually high volatility (60% annualized) combined with high beta shows sizable price swings that can lead to significant short-term correlation divergence despite moderate Pearson correlation (0.40).
This variance means linkage score may underestimate market contagion risk in stress scenarios.

deep_synthesis_insights: Despite moderate correlation, Tesla's extreme beta and volatility create outsized sensitivity to market shocks and index flows, amplifying broad tech sector moves.
Tightening lithium supply + policy-driven demand shifts (credit expiry) form a two-sided stress case uniquely impactful for Tesla via input costs and consumer behavior.
